page.title: 07DAIRY FARMING (NEWICK AREA)
page.content: The most important form of farming in this area is dairy farming. The size of the farm we visited is 1600 acres, of which 450 acres is given over to corn crops (wheat, barley, oats and maize) and peas. The rest is grass, grown for silage.It supports 480 dairy cows and 500 other animals (beef and young dairy). The silage crop takes 6 weeks from being cut, then fertilized, to being cut again. The grass grown here is mainly Melle (plus clover for nitrogen). It is sown in the Autumn and has a life of 5 years. The cattle are Friesans, which are black and white. Their milk, once just for local consumption, now goes to Woodgate Dairy, Sheffield Park, to provide milk for a much larger area. Nothing is removed from the milk at the farm and it takes just 2 days to get from cow to doorstep.
